title: Savernake Forest Cycling and Walks

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / A view west into Savernake Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: A view west into Savernake Forest. The trees here appear to be mostly young beeches.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Concrete ramp, Savernake Forest, near Cadley (1), via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Concrete ramp, Savernake Forest, near Cadley. This structure is situated immediately north of Great Lodge Drive. It appears to be designed as an above-ground vehicle inspection pit. Trucks could be driven up ramps at the rear onto the horizontal section so that their underpinnings could be worked on. It is probably a relic from the war years when the whole forest was used as for ammunition and ordnance storage and distribution

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Braydon Hook House, Savernake Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Braydon Hook House. The property occupies a commanding position on top of a small hill. It sits on the line of an old Roman road. The house is undergoing a major overhaul although there was no activity evident on this day.

images.title: Rob Purvis / Bluebells in West Woods, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bluebells in West Woods

images.title: By Cheesby (Own work) [CC BY-SA 3.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0) or GFDL (http://www.gnu.org/copyleft/fdl.html)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Copper Beeches

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Foxgloves and pines, Savernake Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Foxgloves and pines. These are probably native Digitalis purpurea which can grow to a height of 1.8 metres.

images.title: Brian Robert Marshall / Grand Avenue, Savernake Forest, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grand Avenue. The avenue was laid out in a straight line over 200 years ago and it makes no concessions for rises and falls in the topography.

images.title: Maurice Pullin [CC BY-SA 2.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Grand Avenue 2

description: This large area of woodland is located near Marlborough in the North Wessex Downs AONB. In the woods you'll find miles of walking and cycling trails, with thousands of acres of ancient woodland to explore. As well as the peaceful trails there's a number of ponds, hill climbs, an arboretum, lots of bluebells in the spring and a variety of woodland birds to look out for. There's also some open farmland with grazing cattle and hundreds of beeches and oaks, with tree lined avenues, and coniferous plantations. You can start off from the parking area in the north western corner of the forest, next to the campsite. Then pick up the trails heading south east into forest. For cyclists there's a nice trail running along the Grand Avenue through the centre of the forest. It's part of National Cycle Network Route 4 and you could continue your ride on our Marlborough to Reading Cycle Route. To extend your exercise you could head south east from the forest and visit Bedwyn Common and Great Bedwyn village. Here there are some nice waterside paths along the River Dun to enjoy. Just to the west of the forest you can pick up the long distance Wansdyke Path and visit the nearby West Woods where you'll find more good mountain bike trails and footpaths. In nearby Marlborough you can enjoy a lovely walk along the River Kennet or pick up long distance trails including the Chiseldon and Marlborough Railway Path and the Wessex Ridgeway .

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: Head into Marlborough and there's lots of good options for post exercise refreshments. The Roebuck is a very good choice with great food and a nice beer garden for warmer days. You can find it on London Road at postcode SN8 2AJ.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: There's miles of great wide trails which are ideal for a dog walk. On a fine day you're bound to run into other dogs.

display_address: Grey Ride, Forest Hill, Savernake, Marlborough, Wiltshire, England, SN8 4ND, United Kingdom
